name: Data Wrangling and Exploration

topics.description: Learn the fundamentals of data cleaning, including identifying and handling common issues like missing values, outliers, and inconsistencies. Understand why data cleaning is crucial for ensuring accurate and reliable analysis.
references: James, G., Witten, D., Hastie, T., & Tibshirani, R. (2013). An introduction to statistical learning. Springer.
Wickham, H., & Grolemund, G. (2017). R for data science. O'Reilly Media, Inc.

topics.description: Explore various data transformation techniques, such as scaling, normalization, and encoding, to prepare data for different analysis methods. Understand the impact of these transformations on model performance and interpretability.
references: Alpaydin, E. (2010). Introduction to machine learning. MIT press.
Kuhn, M. (2008). Building predictive models in R using the caret package. Journal of Statistical Software, 28(5), 1-26.

topics.description: Master data aggregation techniques to summarize and condense large datasets. Learn how to group, filter, and calculate aggregate statistics to extract meaningful insights.
references: Kahaner, D., Moler, C.B., & Nash, S. (1989). Numerical methods and software. Prentice Hall.
Grolemund, G., & Wickham, H. (2013). R for data science. O'Reilly Media, Inc.

topics.description: Understand various methods for handling missing data, including imputation and deletion.  Learn the strengths and weaknesses of each approach and how to choose the best method based on the specific dataset and analysis goals.
references: Little, J.M. A., & Rubin, D.B. (2002). Statistical analysis with missing data. John Wiley & Sons.

Azur, M.D., Stuart, E.A., & Breen, R. (2011). The role of missing data in the analysis of data from the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health. Journal of Adolescent Health, 48(3), 271-278.

topics.description: Explore data visualization techniques to gain deeper understanding of your data. Learn how to create various types of charts and graphs to effectively communicate patterns and trends.
references: Cleveland, W.S. (1993). The elements of graphing data. Hobart Freeman.
Wilkinson, L. (2005). The grammar of graphics. Springer.

description: This module delves into the process of preparing data for analysis. Learners will master techniques for cleaning, transforming, and exploring data to uncover patterns and insights.
aims: Cleanse and prepare messy real-world datasets.
Transform data into suitable formats for analysis.
Apply data aggregation and filtering techniques.
Identify and handle missing data effectively.
